title: U.S. Women's History Sites
name: U.S. Women's History Sites
description:
A Map by Ebarnhart

Some major historical sites that tell the story of women's history in the U.S.

properties.name: Abigail Adam's Home
properties.description: Posted by Ebarnhart135 Adams St, Quincy, MAThe nation\'s second First Lady, Abigail Adams was a feminist born before her time. Famous for writing to her husband and the Continental Congress to "She is known for her request that he and the Continental Congress "remember the ladies, and be more generous and favorable to them than your ancestors. Do not put such unlimited power into the hands of the Husbands. Remember all Men would be tyrants if they could. If particular care and attention is not paid to the Ladies we are determined to foment a Rebellion, and will not hold ourselves bound by any Laws in which we have no voice, or Representation."

properties.name: Alice Paul's Home
properties.description: Posted by Ebarnhart128 Hooten Rd, Mt Laurel, NJAlice Paul was a major mover and shaker in the suffrage movement, organizing the Silent Sentinels protests and serving time in jail as a political prisoner. She was also the architect of the Equal Rights Amendment.

properties.name: Arch Street Friends Meeting House
properties.description: Posted by Ebarnhart320 Arch St, Philadelphia, PAAbolitionists and suffragists Sarah Mapps Douglass and Angelina and Sarah Grimke worshipped here.

properties.name: Clara Barton's Home
properties.description: Posted by Ebarnhart5801 Oxford Road, Glen Echo, MDClara Barton tirelessly served wounded soldiers on the battlegrounds of the Civil War and went on to found the American chapter of the International Red Cross.

properties.name: Elizabeth Cady Stanton's Home
properties.description: Posted by Ebarnhart32 Washington Street, Seneca Falls, NYAlong with Susan B. Anthony, she was one of the original founders of the women\'s rights movement and convened the First Women\'s Rights Convention in 1848.

properties.name: Ellen Swallow Richard's Home
properties.description: Posted by Ebarnhart32 Eliot St, Boston, MAEllen Swallow Richards was the foremost female industrial and environmental chemist in the United States in the 1800s and broke numerous scientific barriers including becoming the first woman admitted to MIT, MIT\'s first female instructor, the first woman in America accepted to any school of science and technology, and the first American woman to earn a degree in chemistry.

properties.name: First Women's Rights Convention
properties.description: Posted by Ebarnhart 136 Fall St, Seneca Falls, NYIn 1848, the First Women\'s Rights Convention was held at Wesleyan Chapel in Seneca Falls to discuss women\'s rights in America. At the end of two days, 100 people signed a public commitment to work together to improve women’s quality of life.

properties.name: Helen Keller's Home
properties.description: Posted by Ebarnhart300 West North Commons, Tuscumbia, ALHelen Keller learned to communicate through blindness and deafness with the help of Anne Sullivan. She then went on to advocate for and establish services and assistance to deaf and blind citizens worldwide as well as to participate in the American women\'s rights movement.

properties.name: Jane Addams' Hull House
properties.description: Posted by Ebarnhart800 S Halsted St, Chicago, ILJane Addams and Ellen Gates Starr founded the Hull House, a social settlement, in Chicago in 1889. Serving recent immigrants and ethnic and cultural minorities, the Hull House offered services including kindergarten and day care facilities for the children of working mothers, an employment bureau, libraries, English and citizenship classes, and theater, music and art classes. Upon expansion, it also hosted the Jane Club for single working girls.

properties.name: Maria Mitchell's Home
properties.description: Posted by Ebarnhart4 Vestal St, Nantucket, MAMaria Mitchell was the first woman astronomer in the U.S.

properties.name: National Training School for Women and Girls
properties.description: Posted by Ebarnhart 605 50th Street, NE, Washington, DCNannie Helen Burroughs - a leader in civil, labor, and women\'s rights - founded the National Training School for Women and Girls in 1909 for African-American girls.

properties.name: Nellie Bly's Exposé
properties.description: Posted by EbarnhartRoosevelt Island, New York, NYOne of the nation\'s first daring female reporters, Nellie Bly is best known for her expose of the conditions at the Women\'s Lunatic Asylum on Blackwell\'s Island (now known as Roosevelt Island), as well as her 1889 trip around the world in 72 days.

properties.name: Prudence Crandall's School
properties.description: Posted by Ebarnhart 1 South Canterbury Rd, Canterbury, CTPrudence Crandall, a Quaker schoolteacher, opened a school in January 1832 that, with the admission of an African-American student in 1833, became the the first integrated classroom in the U.S. Even when many Caucasian parents withdrew their daughters from the school and Crandall was briefly jailed in 1832, she continued to operate her school as an institution for "Young ladies and Misses of colour", educating African-American young women from up and down the Eastern Seaboard.

properties.name: Sewall-Belmont House
properties.description: Posted by Ebarnhart144 Constitution Ave NE, Washington, DCHeadquarters of the National Woman\'s Party, Alice Paul set up shop here to fight the fight for women\'s right to vote. She worked from a desk once owned by Susan B. Anthony which can still be found here today.

properties.name: Statue of Elizabeth Blackwell
properties.description: Posted by Ebarnhart629 S Main St, Geneva, NYElizabeth Blackwell was the nation\'s first woman doctor. Earning her MD at Geneva College (now Hobart and William Smith Colleges) in 1849, Blackwell went on to found the New York Infirmary for Women and Children and teach/advocate for medical education for women. Her younger sister, Emily Blackwell, also had a distinguished medical career, was the third woman in the nation to earn an MD, and often worked alongside her sister.

properties.name: Susan B. Anthony's Home
properties.description: Posted by Ebarnhart17 Madison St, Rochester, NYOne of the most famous women in the history of America, Susan B. Anthony was the founder of the women\'s rights movement. While she did not live to see women achieve the right to vote, she was arrested for attempting to cast her own ballot in 1872 and delivered a rousing speech in her defense at trial.

properties.name: The Frances Willard House
properties.description: Posted by Ebarnhart1730 Chicago Ave, Evanston, ILPresident of the Woman\'s Christian Temperance Union and active in the suffrage movement

properties.name: White House
properties.description: Posted by Ebarnhart1600 Pennsylvania Ave NW, Washington, DC 20500Beginning January 10, 1917, the "Silent Sentinels" of the National Woman\'s Party protested in front of the White House. When the U.S. entered World War I, their actions were seen as unpatriotic and several were jailed. Release from imprisonment came on the heels of public outcry over squalid prison conditions.

properties.name: Women's Memorial at Arlington National Cemetery
properties.description: Posted by EbarnhartArlington, VAThe only major national memorial honoring women who served in defense of the U.S.
